data.question: What is the role of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl in the synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion?
data.answer: Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl serves as a CO<sub>2</sub>-to-CO conversion photocatalyst that is covalently attached within a zirconium MOF to enhance CO<sub>2</sub> reduction activity and stability.

data.question: How does the density of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl affect the photocatalytic activity of MOFs?
data.answer: The highest photocatalytic activity was found for MOFs with a density of 3 Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl complexes per unit cell, indicating that an optimum number of Re complexes is necessary for enhanced activity.

data.question: What is the effect of coating Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF on Ag nanocubes for photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion?
data.answer: Coating Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF on Ag nanocubes results in a 7-fold enhancement of CO<sub>2</sub>-to-CO conversion under visible light due to the intensified near-surface electric fields at the surface of Ag nanocubes.

data.question: Why does the photocatalytic activity of MOFs decrease when the density of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl exceeds 4 per unit cell?
data.answer: When the density of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl exceeds 4 per unit cell, the likelihood of Re complexes occupying adjacent linkers increases, leading to weak interactions between contiguous overlapping ReTCs that are not favorable for reducing CO<sub>2</sub> and thus decrease activity.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic performance of Ag⊂Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF stable over time?
data.answer: Yes, Ag⊂Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF shows stable photocatalytic performance throughout a 48-hour period, demonstrating the combined effects of enhanced activity and long-term stability.

data.question: Does the presence of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl in the MOF layer contribute to the photocatalytic activity observed in Ag⊂Re<sub>0</sub>-MOF?
data.answer: False, there was no activity observed in Ag⊂Re<sub>0</sub>-MOF, which lacks Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl in the MOF layer, ruling out the possibility of Ag being responsible for CO production.

data.question: What is the significance of the <italic>fac</italic>-arrangement of ReTC in Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF?
data.answer: The <italic>fac</italic>-arrangement of ReTC in Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF is significant because it maintains the identical geometry compared to the mononuclear Re complex in solution, which is crucial for the photocatalytic activity.

data.question: How does the photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion activity of molecular H<sub>2</sub>ReTC compare to that of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF?
data.answer: Molecular H<sub>2</sub>ReTC deactivates within the first hour of photocatalysis, whereas Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF shows enhanced stability and maintains its activity, indicating that Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF is more effective for photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion.

data.question: Can the photocatalytic activity of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF be attributed to the proximity of photoactive centers?
data.answer: Yes, the increase in photocatalytic activity from Re<sub>1</sub> to Re<sub>3</sub> suggests that the bimolecular reaction pathway, which involves proximity between photoactive centers, is the source of higher turnover.

data.question: Does the photocatalytic activity enhancement observed in Ag⊂Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF depend on the thickness of the MOF layer?
data.answer: True, a thinner Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF layer on Ag nanocubes leads to superior turnover due to the stronger electric field influence on average, resulting in up to 7-fold enhancement of photocatalytic activity.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion activity of Cu⊂Re<sub>2</sub>-MOF enhanced in a similar manner to Ag⊂Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF?
data.answer: False, activity enhancement was not observed in Cu⊂Re<sub>2</sub>-MOF as the Cu nanoparticles do not have localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) characteristics that match the absorption features of ReTC.

data.question: What is the role of triethylamine in the photocatalytic experiments?
data.answer: Triethylamine serves as a sacrificial electron donor in the acetonitrile/triethylamine mixture saturated with CO<sub>2</sub> during the photocatalytic experiments.

data.question: How does the presence of Ag nanocubes influence the photocatalytic activity of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF?
data.answer: The presence of Ag nanocubes influences the photocatalytic activity of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF by generating intensified near-surface electric fields at their surface plasmon resonance frequency, which enhances the photocatalytic activity.

data.question: Does the photocatalytic CO<sub>2</sub> conversion activity of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF decrease in the absence of CO<sub>2</sub>?
data.answer: True, in the absence of CO<sub>2</sub> (under Ar atmosphere), there was no CO generation observed, indicating that the presence of CO<sub>2</sub> is essential for the photocatalytic activity of Re<sub>3</sub>-MOF.

data.question: What is the effect of varying the density of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl on the molecular environment within MOFs for CO<sub>2</sub> catalytic turnover?
data.answer: Varying the density of Re<sup>I</sup>(CO)<sub>3</sub>(BPYDC)­Cl affects the structural environment within the MOF interior, influencing the vibrational stretching modes of ReTC carbonyl ligands and potentially the electron back-donation to the carbonyl ligand from Re of other ReTCs, which impacts the CO<sub>2</sub> catalytic turnover.
